title: How do shape and symmetry influence the polarity of a molecule? - Quora

response.answer_text: A molecule is termed as polar if it possesses a permanent electric dipole. Examples of such molecules are H₂O, HCl, NH₃, and O₃ (ozone, mind you!). Shape and symmetry of a molecule are best understood by means of Group Theory applied to Chemistry¹, i.e. with the help of some math. What we do is classify molecules based on their symmetry, namely the presence (or lack thereof) of certain elements of symmetry². The classification of objects or molecules according to this originates the so-called point groups³. There are specific procedures to determine which point group a molecule belongs to. It is best to summarise them on a flowchart:  It turns out that only molecules that belong to the point groups C𝘯, C𝘯𝘷, and C𝘴 have shapes such that originate a permanent electric dipole. Moreover, in the case of molecules belonging to the point groups C𝘯 and C𝘯𝘷, said dipole must lie on the main rotational axis C𝘯. Examples: ozone, O₃, has the following molecular shape:  O₃ is said to be a bent (or angular) molecule; it belongs to the C₂𝘷 point group and is polar (its dipole moment is about 0.5 D). On the other hand, CO₂ is a typical linear molecule belonging to the D∞𝘩 group: this means it cannot be polar - indeed, its dipole moment is 0 D.
